author: barnabemonnot
content: it would need to bump something that is nontrivial. perhaps `true_bribe = min(fee_cap, bribe)` is the correct quantity. in the example I gave, if you only bump the bribe after 10 Gwei your true bribe is constant. we could require that true bribe be greater than 10% its value before the replace or some such rule

author: sky.cactus
content: Maybe require bumping both?

author: barnabemonnot
content: yeah but i might not need to bump my fee cap

author: sky.cactus
content: If your transaction has fee cap below base fee, no amount of bribe bumping will actually change what you pay.

author: barnabemonnot
content: if i carefully set it to 100 and my bribe is at 10, there is still some way to go

author: sky.cactus
content: Actually, I don't think there e is anything that is easy to evaluate that will ensure the user pays more.  ðŸ¤”

author: sky.cactus
content: If you are blocked by base fee, you will pay base fee plus min miner bribe no matter what.

author: sky.cactus
content: Unless you bump cap *past* the current base fee by enough that the bribe becomes meaningful, but that is very non-trivial to evaluate and only allows a single replace by fee opportunity for any transaction and could require a huge fee bump.

author: barnabemonnot
content: yes the basefee is another issue. the true bribe bumping at least guarantees that it terminates (in the sense, it's not free to bump and at some point when you are passed basefee, you are guaranteed to pay), but not that the fee cap is above basefee

author: sky.cactus
content: Brainstorming: we could introduce a new variable in transactions that is min_miner_bribe and is used explicitly for RBF.

author: sky.cactus
content: It would default to 0, and increase only when issuing RBF.

author: barnabemonnot
content: I would feel weird having any rule that depends on basefee, since basefee varies over time, it seems overly subjective, as in I could replace by fee with a meaningless bump in current basefee conditions but meaningful later on

author: sky.cactus
content: Alternatively, introduce expiring transactions and get rid of RBF entirely.  But this comes with its own problems.

author: barnabemonnot
content: RBF = replace-by-fee?

author: sky.cactus
content: Bitcoin got rid of RBF in most clients/miners IIRC.

author: sky.cactus
content: I do think cancellation is valuable though, so I'm a bit loath to remove it.

author: barnabemonnot
content: yes i think the true bribe rule above eventually terminates but it wouldn't terminate as fast as a basefee-based rule would. it would get rid of the subjectivity though

author: sky.cactus
content: A special cancellation transaction that is just alltruisticaly respected could work in most situations.

author: sky.cactus
content: What do you mean by "terminates"?

author: sky.cactus
content: And what do you mean by "true bribe rule"?

author: barnabemonnot
content: oh but that doesn't work great in this case for instance: my current fee cap is 10, my bribe is 5 and basefee is at 100. I might want to do feecap 110 and keep my bribe at 5

author: barnabemonnot
content: so this example where i keep replacing the bribe but not the fee cap means I can send "valid" transactions infinitely, it doesn't terminate

author: barnabemonnot
content: the true bribe rule says your replacement transaction must have a true bribe greater than `1+x` times the true bribe of the original transaction, where true bribe is `min(fee cap, bribe)` and `x` is for instance 12.5%

author: barnabemonnot
content: it terminates because at some point you must be increasing to some meaningful bribe value

author: barnabemonnot
content:
but it might be too stringent, e.g., it doesn't allow you to do this:
> my current fee cap is 10, my bribe is 5 and basefee is at 100. I might want to do feecap 110 and keep my bribe at 5

author: sky.cactus
content: The thing we want to ensure is that in order for a transaction with the same nonce to propagate across the network, it has non-zero cost to the user.  I think you are saying that bumping bribe alone doesn't ensure that (and I agree).

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm leaning more towards an explicit cancellation transaction.  We can have that transaction type include a `min_bribe` that must be higher than `miner_bribe`.  I think that addresses most of the legitimate use cases for RBF transactions.

author: phabc
content: Wouldn't a cancellation require a state update? Seems like overall it would increase chain congestion, especially during intense periods where this could create a positive feedback loop.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!278762485497069569> Cancellation transactions would just be a new type of transaction that is guaranteed to do nothing but deduct gas and bump nonce.

author: sky.cactus
content: The nice thing about it here is that we can have it include another gas field in the transaction that ensures it costs *more* than any transaction it replaces.

author: sky.cactus
content: I argued it could be less, since it is guaranteed to only touch one account (and miner balance like every transaction), while an ETH send is priced based on the assumption it will touch two accounts.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!211091239112671234> argued that we should be careful going below 21,000 gas for *anything* just due to the cost of handling pending pools and gossip and whatnot.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm somewhat ambivalent on the exact cost of this transaction.

author: phabc
content: Well eth transfers always touches two accounts unless the coinbase is transferring to self, but I get your argument

author: holiman
content: Well... on the one hand, we already have cancellation by e.g. "sending to self". The only reason to want something different, IMO, is to make it cheaper, right? But making cancellation easier/cheaper also makes attacks based on building transaction-towers that are later collapsed (e..g due to replacing the bottom-most tx with something which makes the rest become moot). There are various intricacies when dealing with transactions, e..g  https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/issues/21460 , and having another different type for cancelling, instead of cancelling simply being a subset of a regular tx doesn't make things easier, IMO.

author: holiman
content:
> I do think cancellation is valuable though

We already have it though, so no need to add another one ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!211091239112671234> The new reason for a cancellation transaction (brought up above a ways) is because we can no longer easily guarantee that a given transaction will cost the user more as of 1559.

author: sky.cactus
content: This is different from my original motivations, which you successfully killed for the most part.  ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: That is, we can no longer just do a simple RBF send 0 ETH to self as a cancellation transaction if 1559 is introduced.

author: sky.cactus
content:
Options for replace-by-fee (RBF) under 1559:
1. Remove RBF entirely (Bitcoin did it, we can too!)
2. Add notable complexity to clients to try to identify whether a transaction will *probably* pay more gas or not.
3. Introduce a new transaction type that *guarantees* the user pays more gas with the replacement, and make it so that this transaction type can *only* cancel.
4. Introduce another field in EIP-1559 transactions (`min_miner_bribe`) that all transactions have to include but would be set to `0` for all transactions that were not RBF transactions.

author: sky.cactus
content: The advantage of (3) over (4) is that we don't have every transaction be 1 byte bigger just to *enable* RBF.  If we don't care about growing the transaction by a byte on the wire and having one more decoding step then (4) is better.

author: phabc
content:
> The new reason for a cancellation transaction (brought up above a ways) is because we can no longer easily guarantee that a given transaction will cost the user more as of 1559.
One issue though is that this could still create some positive feedback loop in blockspace crunch periods, where people will continually send "cancel" txs to bump resubmit their previous tx, which will lead to more tx having to be cancelled. High demand is also when EIP-1559 helps us the least, so fee volatility will be high and hard to predict.

author: sky.cactus
content: 1559 doesn't help the least with high demand, it helps the least with high *rate of change in demand*.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!278762485497069569> I think you are just describing the general problem with RBF?

author: sky.cactus
content: Expiring transactions would address the most common legitimate need for RBF IMO, and it is easier on the network.

author: sky.cactus
content: However, it would break the current invariant that "once a transaction is valid, it will remain valid forever".

author: phabc
content: With bumping gas price you don't need to send *another tx*, you just resubmit the same tx

author: sky.cactus
content: ~~You do currently.~~ Those are the same thing currently.

author: phabc
content: Sure, but only one tx is included

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes, cancellation and expiration would both share that behavior.

author: phabc
content: How so? Cancelation increases the nonce of your original tx

author: phabc
content: You still need to resubmit your original tx

author: sky.cactus
content: Oh, no.  It would behave just like any other transaction.

author: sky.cactus
content: It doesn't change anything about a current transaction, it just would be a transaction type that doesn't *do* anything (but still respects current nonce semantics).

author: phabc
content: But it costs gas, right?

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes.

author: phabc
content:
So say I have tx `z` and I need to bump it in price 5 times, because fee market moves too quickly. Say the final gas price is `p`.

Currently, I only spend `z.gasLimit * p`.

With cancellation, I would need to spend `z.gasLimit * p + 5 * cancelation_gas_amount * p`

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, I see what you are saying.

author: sky.cactus
content: Cancellation transactions result in an extra 21,000 gas when your goal is simply "increase fee".

author: sky.cactus
content: I argue that with 1559, "bumping fee" will rarely be necessary, especially for end-users.  If users are setting `fee_cap` to their actual willingness to pay, then they'll be included in the first block that isn't more than 2x full where base fee is below `base_fee + miner_bribe_demand`.  If we are correct in our estimation that less than 5% of blocks will be more than 2x full, then this means that regular users should basically never need to fee bump.

author: sky.cactus
content: However, there *are* times when you want to cancel your transaction because it is taking to long.  For example, if your fee_cap is 100, and base fee is holding steady at 150 for a month, you may (likely?) no longer want your transaction to go through.

author: sky.cactus
content: I suspect that in an EIP-1559 world, cancellations will be the common use-case for RBF, and fee bumping will only be done by bots who are participating in aggressive gas wars and such.

author: sky.cactus
content: If we had expiring transactions, then we would be solving the end-user problem that I believe requires RBF, at which point I would be much more in favor of just getting rid of RBF from clients entirely since it would now only really serve competitive bots who I care little for supporting (and who should really be submitting transactions directly to miners via backchannels anyway).

author: sky.cactus
content: Without expiring transactions, cancellation transactions would get the job done, though not quite as user-friendly as expirations IMO.

author: phabc
content: And why can't we do what we have today, say by enforcing that `new_max_cap + new_bribe` is higher than `old_max_cap + old_bribe`? So long as they increase one or the other, it should be fine

author: sky.cactus
content: Because that doesn't guarantee that the user will *actually* pay more.

author: sky.cactus
content:
Current `base_fee`: 200
First transaction: `miner_bribe: 1`, `fee_cap: 50`
Second transaction: `miner_bribe: 2`, `fee_cap: 100`
Base fee reduces to 49: transaction is included with miner receiving 1 and 49 being burned.

author: sky.cactus
content: Though, in writing this out I realize that maybe we can lean on the fact that the base fee can only change so fast and *most of the time* we don't have miners mining empty blocks when there are pending transactions?

author: sky.cactus
content: ðŸ¤”  though, this doesn't necessarily help from a selfish mining perspective.  Imagine the same scenario but the base_fee dropped to `99`, the miner earns `1` regardless of which transaction they choose to include, so why bother including the newer one?

author: sky.cactus
content: Perhaps the answer is simply because that is an edge case that the miner won't bother optimizing for?

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm being swayed that we can just require an increase in both the fee cap and the miner bribe.

author: phabc
content: I think I prefer both being increased too now that I think about it. It's almost like forcing the miner_bribe to go up if increasing fee_cap  acts as a "fee" for them replacing your tx

author: timbeiko
content:
Does anyone here understand this:

In his post about Rollups being core to the ETH scaling roadmap (https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/a-rollup-centric-ethereum-roadmap/4698), Vitalik said we need: 
> EIP 1559,  both for the ETH burn and for the benefit of making it easy to send transactions that almost certainly get into the next block (which rollups still depend on for confirmations)

I understand why the next block inclusion matters (rollup operators posting updates on chain), but what does the burn have to do with rollups?

author: sky.cactus
content: It solves a security problem with Ethereum.

author: sky.cactus
content: If Ethereum is a data availability chain for rollups, we should care greatly about its security against large reorgs.

author: sky.cactus
content: Which means addressing the current open security vulnerability related to selfish mining.

author: randomuser9550
content: He's only saying what parts of what currently are being worked on are relevant given that the major concern is rollups. The hex binary thing also has nothing to do with rollups.

author: sky.cactus
content: The hex binary thing has to do with layer 1 scaling and performance I believe, which is related to rollup efficiency.

author: timbeiko
content: Here's a report from the community outreach work I've been doing with the Cat Herders over the past few weeks to get feedback on 1559: https://medium.com/ethereum-cat-herders/eip-1559-community-outreach-report-aa18be0666b5
